 This is an entirely seperate issue than "my right to swing my fist ends at your nose". If you really wanted such an example to work, it would have to be "You have no right to swing your fist because you might hit somebody in the nose, and we are going to handcuff you to ensure that you DONT swing that fist".
 
 The argument for limitations on constitutionally protected rights has always been that your rights are absolute so long as they do not infringe upon the rights of others. This has been twisted around into "your rights are absolute except where suspending them may be good for the population at large".
 
 The former is certainly reasonable, and is what you were illustrating with your fist-nose example. The latter is a way of thinking dangerous to individual liberty because once you go down that road, you can justify anything. We recently saw our presidents representatives argue in his behalf in front of the supreme court that the executive rbanch of our government should be allowed to hold American citizens, on American soil, without benifit of legal representation, trila or charges, and that they should be able to do this secretly. The argument they used for suspension of habeus corpus was basically the same one being used to defend searches at airports without probable cause.

 The TSA does not need probable cause to search you. You agree to be searched when you buy a ticket from a major airline. It is a contract between you and the airline when you buy the ticket. You give them money and your 4th Amendment, they give you transport.
 
 If you don't like the terms of the contract, then don't enter into the contract. You don't have the right to make the airline give you transport. There are other carriers that will let you aboard with no searches. Enter into the contract with them if you don't want to be searched.
